text:
It's a real privilege to welcome
Steve Blank as our speaker for today. A man who needs very little
introduction here at Stanford

certainly has had a huge
impact on me personally. So I may not be biased. But quick intro, I'll just
cover four aspects of Steve.

We'll start out
with entrepreneur. Had at least eight startups. And Steve, correct
me if I'm wrong.

A really successful one was
Epiphany but had some others. And you look at any list of the
most influential entrepreneurs

in the Valley over the
last several decades. You'll see Steve's
names on the list, so
real successful entrepreneur. I would say author--

from his entrepreneur
experience, he wrote a book called Four
Steps to the Epiphany, which is largely credited with
starting the lean startup

movement, which he also
had a big role in, Eric Ries and others. And author-- just all the
great defense magazines,

a famous Harvard
Business Review, the "Lean Start-Up Changes
Everything," very prolific.

Just look at the defense blogs
lately at any given week, and you see something
that Steve writes,

again, had some really, really
successful and still impactful pieces. And there's more to come
where that came from.

So yeah, entrepreneur,
author, educator-- he's been here at Stanford when
he should have been hanging out

in his beach resort there on
the coast, which some of you-- who went there? Anyone make it
there last weekend?

OK, pretty amazing, right? Why would you drive
over the mountain? Because he cares
about all of you, and that's why he's here,
so amazing educator.

Started something
called Innovation-Corps, which some of may
have heard of, which was taken on by and funded
by the National Science
Foundation and [INAUDIBLE]. Steve, I don't know. What was the total number? Like, 100-plus schools? I mean, it's a lot, right?

Lots-- Six countries, three countries. Yeah, so huge impact. NSF, NIH, DOE, and
NSA, et cetera.

And look at Steve
Blank's blog because it's a much better
introduction than I'm going to be able to give tonight
in a span of a few minutes.

You need a good hour to read it. And taught a widely
popular course here called the Lean LaunchPad,
which students lined up in a--

still a very
successful course that launched a lot of-- the term
Get Rich U. for Stanford was largely associated with
some of the work Steve did here

and all the successful
student teams that come through his classes. I've met Steve--

I'd been in the
military for a long time and was doing
traditional security work but met Steve and was
a big life pivot for me

when we got together along with
Pete Newell and built the course called Hacking for Defense,
which took a lot of his lessons

from Lean LaunchPad
in his methodology and applied it to
defense challenge,

intelligence
community challenges, so incredibly successful
or effective and impactful

educator. So what do we got? We have entrepreneur,
author, educator. Oh, Hacking for
Defense, that scale

to other-- that hacking
for-- hacking for climate, hacking for oceans,
hacking for diplomacy. I mean, we are solving a lot
of public sector problems

with the work that started
with Lean LaunchPad. And then it became
Hacking for Defense.

The last one I'll
save is patriot. So little known
fact about Steve is coming from an immigrant
background, a New York City guy.

The saying-- I said this
before in class-- you can take the boy out
of New York City, but you can hear
New York in Steve. But as a teenager, went
off to Southeast Asia

during the Vietnam War, which
none of you were alive at. I was barely alive. And so there he was, hanging
bombs off of fighter jets,

bombing the North Vietnamese,
so a real patriot. And that didn't stop there. I would argue what
he's doing now

is a real reflection on his
commitment to public service and patriotism. He's done a lot
of defense boards,

close advisor to the
intelligence community, spends a lot of time in
rooms with no windows that he can't tell people where he is
at that undisclosed location,

and extends beyond the
US to include our allies and partners like the
UK, so a lot of things.

Steve, entrepreneur, author,
educator, patriot, and friend,

over to you. Thanks, Joe. It sure sounds like a
description of someone with attention deficit disorder,
which is probably true.

How many of you sat through a
couple of the week sessions? How many of you sat
through some of them? So what you heard was stories
of entrepreneurs selling

to the Department of Defense. Anybody interested in
doing that as a startup? Anybody?

One of the things I tend to look
at now in my career is not only, are those stories war stories?

And "war stories" with quotes,
meaning commercial war stories. Is there a pattern here?

That is, is there something
you could learn and extract from all those stories?

Is there a model on
how to learn from what each one of those companies
was trying to tell you

about their adventure
in trying to attack the Department of
Defense as a customer?

Does that make sense? And so what I'm
going to do today is try to give you some
heuristics, some of the things I extracted from
their conversation,

and then see if we could kind
of get some Q&A going for those of you who are interested
in actually selling

to the Department of Defense or
potentially interested in doing that. I should remind you that this
version of Silicon Valley

and Defense is only
about 70 years old. We reinvent ourselves as a
valley and our relationship

with the DoD almost
every 10 or 15 years. But what's new today is the
fact that venture capital firms

have stood up and started to
just focus on funding companies, either doing what's called
dual use, which I'll

explain in a second,
or direct sales to the Department of Defense. And that is new. That's a real opportunity.

The other thing that's really
new is that, for the first time ever, at least parts of
the DoD have understood

that they no longer own all
the technology to deter or win a war. That's a big idea.

It used to be, for the
entire history of the United States and other
nations, the military

owned all the
advanced technology. Even in the beginning of
the 21st century, drones,

owned by the military. Imaging satellites in space,
owned by the military.

Signal intelligence satellites
in space, owned by the military. Autonomy, owned by the military.

The world's most advanced
semiconductor labs, which they still won't
tell you where they are, owned by the military.
Advanced research in cyber, NSA. Guess what? None of that is true anymore.

It's not that the
military doesn't have advanced labs and all
the services and other places.

But in fact, think
about how much-- anybody know how much we're
going to invest in Silicon Valley just in AI in 2024?

Anybody? Guess the number. Anybody know what that is? Take a guess. I'm going to cold
call in a minute.

Sir? $200 billion. $200 billion, close,
but a little-- $50 billion, right?

$50 billion. Anybody understand what's the
total R&D budget for the DoD?

A lot less than that. So think about a
commercial venture capital is going to invest
more money in AI

than the sum of all
the research labs in the Department of Defense. Now, it doesn't mean we're
going to fall behind.

It just means that the
Department of Defense now needs to figure
out how to buy things from commercial companies
when they were never organized

and still are not organized
to do so at scale. That's this impedance match
that we're talking about.

The DoD is trying
to figure it out and venture capital
and startups are trying to figure out
about how to have

effective communication and
not just one-offs but at scale. Anybody know what
the MDAP list is?

Anybody know what that is? Anybody hear that phrase? You got to go look
it up after class. It's called the Major
Defense Acquisition Programs.

It's a list of the tier
one or top 100 or so things

that the Department of Defense
spends their most money on. How many startups do you
think are on that list?
How many? Sir? Zero. Correct. Zero. How many should be on it?

Every year, there
should be more. That is, I think, the
goal of Kath Hicks. But it's really hard if you're
an incumbent prime where you're

putting jobs in every
congressional district, and you're the major donor to
every congressional campaign

of the House and Senate
Armed Services Committee and Appropriations Committee. So that's a real problem
of an impedance matching

between what's available
on the commercial space and what the prime contractors
have owned for the last three

or four decades. With that, does that
make sense as an intro? I want to give you a
couple of heuristics

or a couple of
observations how I think about go-to-market
strategies for startups selling

to the DoD. Now, this is not the bible. This is a set of heuristics,
set of opinions, set of rules,

et cetera, that will
change over time. If you're a Stanford
technologist,

it's really interesting to
differentiate your technology with problems and requirements.

In general, no one in
the DoD, in general, cares about your tech. The DoD buys solutions
to real problems.

And they buy things
that are matching what they call requirements.

They've already figured
out the problems, and they've specified
the thing they want. That's a requirement.

The first question,
if you're going to start a company
that you want to sell into the Department
of Defense, do

you understand what these
problems or requirements are? And I will show you a little
later how to figure that out.

But if you can't
answer that question, all you have is a
great set of ideas and a great set
of shiny objects.

But you don't have a
company, in my opinion.  If you understand
problems and requirements,

those lead to the
quickest orders because you can find the
people who have them. And they will eventually
raise their hand.

And you can actually
talk to them and find out whether there's
a match between their problems

and your solution or what
you could build for them. Now, in some cases,
your technology

may be seeing Over The
Horizon, OTH, as I call it. No one has identified a
problem or a requirement.

It might not be
ready for VC funding. But actually, the
Department of Defense has figured this out decades ago
and has some really neat funding

opportunities called
the SBIR program. Every military service has
what's called the SBIR, S-B-I-R,

which is free money, seriously,
millions of dollars of free money. And they take no equity.

It's essentially a grant. And later in this
presentation, I will show you which
service has which program.

And you could go
online and apply for it if you're preseed
or in R&D, and you

want to take your
technology a little further. And it's a great onboarding for
particularly Stanford technology

companies. Makes sense so far? All right, selling
to the government has no commercial parallels.

Anybody ever been in
business-to-business sales? Anybody? A couple.

You know nothing about
selling to the government. And I'm smiling saying that. It's not like you
don't know anything.

But trust me, I built
a company and selling to commercial companies. My head exploded when
I had to figure out

how to sell to the government. It is the most unbelievable
process in the world, and that's not good.

In fact, the equivalent is
for relative sales complexity, business-to-consumer is like
taking candy from a baby.

And what I mean by that is,
gee, here's one customer. You can figure out
what their needs are. You go do a lot of
customer discovery.

You figure out, gee, here's the
problem, or here's the need. Do we have what's called
product/market fit? The buyer is typically the user.

It's not that hard. That's business-to-consumer. Makes sense? Business-to-business is a
little more complicated.

It's like picking
someone's pocket. It's not like taking
candy from a baby. But there are more
people, as we'll see,

involved in a
business-to-business sale. But there are an
infinite ways to do this.

Companies are only organized
in about three or four models. Companies are
organized functionally,

or they're organized
by division, or they're organized by
matrix organizations. But that's about it.

I mean, there's not 500
different types of companies. And you could
figure out not only what the organization
chart looks like

but what the influence
map looks like, et cetera, with a sufficient discovery. But the government?

Government looks like this. It's really a mess. It's a mess and a
huge opportunity.

It's a mess because just
figuring out where to start is hard. And it's a mess, as we'll
describe a little later,

is getting a first order
from the government does not guarantee that you have a
profitable and sustainable and

scalable company. In fact, sometimes it's a trap. At least in these
other businesses,

you could predict
whether this thing is a repeatable and
scalable business model. In the government, much harder.

And I'll explain why. And by the way, there's a kind
of a fourth type of company called dual-use companies,
which actually are companies

that sell commercially and sell
to the Department of Defense.

Lots of opinions
about whether this is an effective approach or not. I kind of diagrammed my
view of what it looks like.

If you're an
early-stage company, one of your biggest problems,
that is, when you first begin,

is that you barely have enough
resources to do one thing. And the sales process
is radically different.

The resources you
build, the people you build, the go-to-market
strategies you build are completely different in
commercial and DoD sales.

And so figuring out how to do
that all on day one is tough. Plus, some of the engineering
requirements and security

requirements for selling to
the Department of Defense also have much more
stringent requirements

than commercial world. And also things like
intellectual property rights and who owns things
also differs radically.

So I'm not suggesting you
don't want to do dual use. But when you hear that
phrase, don't just think it's some magic panacea
if I could sell commercially,

and then I could sell to
the DoD all on day one. Paul Kwan is not here tonight,
has a heuristic that says,

he won't let us startups
think about dual use until they get to $100
million in revenue. And then they have sufficient
resources to do that.

Other VCs have other opinions. So I won't make you
read this table.

But later on, you could
get a copy of these slides. And see, here's a
summary, in my mind, of some of the differences.

The sales processes
are different. The types of selling
is different. The types of individuals you
need, their domain expertise

is different. The barriers to
entry, it's real easy to sell business-to-business.

Selling to the government,
really, where do I start? How do I find out
who needs what?

Gee, how do I compete
with Lockheed and General Dynamics and somebody else? And are they partners?

Or are they saboteurs? Or are they something else? How do I figure out what the
criteria to buy something is?

Gee, in a commercial world,
at least business-to-business or business-to-consumer, that's
pretty upfront about like,

and fast rules, et cetera. If you ever think there's
bureaucracy selling to large

corporations, you don't
understand the word "bureaucracy." This is where you're
all supposed to laugh.

Selling to the
government and the DoD, you will encounter one of the
world's largest bureaucracies--

3 million people, multiple
organizations, different rules, different things you have
to agree to, et cetera.

Partnerships-- partnerships
in the commercial world are for cost reduction, access
to customers, et cetera.

Partnerships in the DoD
or selling to the DoD might mean you're
working with gatekeepers,

like a prime contractor or a
sub that actually understands all that paperwork but basically
wants to use you for leverage

and then maybe take all
your IP, and then you're left in the dark.

And then funding--
it's relatively easy to explain to
venture capitalists about a business-to-consumer
or a business-to-business play.

Here's one of the
interesting things about selling to the Department
of Defense and getting funded.

If I'm a venture
capitalist right now and I could put money in
a software AI company,

what do you think the
returns are I'm looking at? What kind of multiple
do you think I will get?

Sir? More than 20 times [INAUDIBLE]. Yeah, "obscene" is
actually the right word.

I'm looking for a
hundred or a thousand. I mean, it's just crazy. Now, I'm going to put
money in a company selling

to the Department of Defense. What kind of returns
am I going to get? Any idea?

[INAUDIBLE] multiple,
I don't know, 5x. Maybe, if we're Lockheed. Why? You're going to go public?

Is Lockheed going to buy you? Is Lockheed going to pay that
same multiple that software AI company could get?

Probably not. So now all of a sudden,
there's this impedance mismatch between what
investors are looking

at on one side of I could
put my money over here versus I could put my
money into DoD investments.

The good news, as I
said when we started, is that there's now a wave of
defense venture capitalists who

are mission driven, who are
not as focused on 100x but are focused on doing the right
things for the country.

Two of them are your instructors
in this class, Ernestine and Paul Kwan. They both are investing
in DoD startups

because it's the
right mission to do. And you get a return but
not at the same rate. Ernestine, is that a
fair statement or not?

Looking to get good returns. Looking to get good returns but
not the returns of an OpenAI or someone else,
just not possible.

And we'll talk a
little more about this. So the upside on a commercial
company is unlimited.

The upside on a DoD startup,
limited but not bad,

but just limited. So let me remind you
of kind of in general.

Anybody who want to start
besides a DoD company, any kind of startup in this room? Anybody?

Come on. No one in the middle wants
to start a company, really?

Here's a set of rules for
whatever business you're in. You ready? Really important.

Here's what you're
looking for in customers. Do they have a problem? Or do they have a
written requirement?

If they don't have
one, then you're just trying to throw
technology into people who don't really care.

Two is, do they know
they have a problem? Seriously? If they don't know
they have a problem,

boy, you're now trying
to educate folks. You don't have enough
bandwidth and time as a startup to do that.

You're looking for people
who have a problem. And they go, yeah, I
really have a problem.

And the world's most perfect
people who have a problem and know they have
a problem, they've

been actively looking
for a solution. In the DoD, it might
be special forces. Our lives are dependent
on solving this problem.

Or in the South China
Sea, [? GB ?] odds aren't for us anymore. We're actively looking to
change the multiplication force

multiplier. We're in the Red Sea. We need something cheaper than
just using million-dollar SM-3s

to shoot down $20,000 drones. And it'd be great if they
already assembled the solution

out of piece parts. We're using SM-3s to
shoot down Houthi drones. But that really
isn't cost effective.

We're going to run
out of those things. Gee, is there some other
way to solve this problem? Makes sense so far?

But most importantly, for
our startup, do they have or can they acquire a budget?

These are the only type
of people on day one, in my opinion, that
you could afford

to spend time with in the
early days of a startup. Doesn't mean in the mainstream
you don't talk to other people.

But the early days, you
just don't have the time and bandwidth to be
in an educational mode

unless you're building
something over the horizon. But if you think you have
a product and service, these people exist.

And I'll show you some
areas where they do. Feel free to interrupt or
ask questions as we go along.

So if you take this
model, essentially, this

is product/market fit. That is, do I
understand their needs?

And do I have a solution
that fits product/market fit? When you're selling
to a consumer

in a business-to-consumer
marketplace, here's essentially
one person you need to worry about of whether
you understand their needs.

They're the user, but they're
also the payer, so a big idea, user and payer, one person.

Sometimes there are other,
but it's pretty low. Does that make sense so far? I don't want to go further.

Product/market fit in B-to-C,
you see something online. You could click the button.

You could pay for it. That's product/market fit
in business-to-consumer.

If I'm selling in the
enterprise, that is, to other companies, well,
there are multiple players.

And I used to get this confused. Oh, the users really
love our product. Used to make this
mistake all the time.

Do the users have the
budget in the company? Oh, no, they don't. Who has the budget?

Oh, it's someone in finance. Oh, well, there's another
set of product/market fit.

I need to get product/market
fit if the users care. But if the payers don't
care, I don't have a sale.

And there might be
technical recommenders. If they don't care, can they
say, no, this is a bad idea?

That's another
product/market fit. Anybody ever sell something
in the enterprise at all?
Anybody? Anybody know what a saboteur is? What's a saboteur?

Someone in the
customer organization that doesn't believe
in your product. Yeah, and what will they do? Sabotage.

Sabotage the sale. So there's usually another
product/market fit, right? And lots of strategies. Do you steamroll them?
Do you try to co-opt them? Et cetera. So there are multiple levels. They're usually less than four.

But you need to understand
the real mistake is confusing the users love
you and stopping there.

Well, they loved us in B-to-C.
That was a sale, not true in the enterprise. You're with me so far?

This is a nightmare. In the DoD, at
minimum, there are 5, if not 10 or 20, people
who need to-- boxes

need to be checked to actually
get a significant order. Let me go back.

So the question is,
how do I find them? Where are they? How do I address them? Et cetera.
Does that make sense so far? B-to-C, B-to-B, B-to-G.

Now, what's interesting
is Paul Kwan came up with a set of
heuristics or a set of ways

to think about the different
types of strategies to go-to-market, which
means start your sales

plan in selling to the DoD. He said, there's one
model that starts,

as Ernestine pointed
out, that says, anybody have a billion dollars? That's how you start build
it, and they will come.

Literally, Palantir,
SpaceX, Anduril, kind of almost household names
started with billionaires

who said, we could
afford to beat our head against the wall for a
decade until we actually get significant traction inside
the Department of Defense.

SpaceX, as some of
you might remember, had to sue the Air
Force for decades to actually get them
to allow them to build

on national security launches. Palantir had to sue
the Army to do that. Anduril, I think, had a little
easier because they kind of

learned from some
of those activities. But basically, the leverage here
was private capital at scale

to build the innovation
ahead of the requirements. They basically said, we think
we have some good instincts

about what to build. We're going to build ahead of
requirements we think we know.

This was an
over-the-horizon strategy. And we're going to reduce
risk by also having

a dual-use commercial strategy. Remember, SpaceX is
actually amortizing the cost
of military launches with what? What do they launch mostly? Commercial.
What kind of commercial? Satellites. What kind of satellites? Communications. What's it called?

Starlink. Starlink, right? They basically, so far,
has built, what is it, $6 billion here, a business of
creating their own commercial

entity, which is amortizing
the cost of the Falcon 9s that they're also developed
to be reusable,

which drove down the cost
of commercial launches, so a factor of 10 or less
than United Launch Alliance,

which finally forced the US Air
Force to pay attention and now the Space Force to pay attention
that this is insane to be paying

these kinds of prices to ULA
and finally allow SpaceX to bid on that.

[? Andrew ?] has
done this, but just on technology innovation
about adopting autonomy and AI and
other things, much faster

than a lot of the incumbents. This was a build it,
and they will come. But this only works if you
have a ton of capital upfront,

and you potentially could build
a dual-use commercial business at the same time.

There's another completely
opposite strategy, which is bottoms up. To me, the three good
examples are Vannevar Labs--

and I think we heard
from them in this class-- OneBrief, and TurbineOne. That's incredible
functionality, so good

and so clearly differentiated. It makes it easy to buy. This is like night and day from
anything else they have online.

In the commercial world, we
call this product-led growth. That's another path
to selling to the DoD.

There's another
one where you use these advisors and these
ex-agency government officials

who are now still widely
respected inside the military. But they're now working in
venture and in private equity.

And then another one, radical
collaboration-- you partner with the primes. Instead of competing
with the primes,

you actually take
advantage of the fact that they've been
working the system. They have more lobbyists
than you probably

have people in your company. And at least in the
beginning of your company, you use all their leverage
to become a subcontractor.

And you focus on
your core skills until one day,
you actually learn all the things they know about
in actually operating in the DoD

system. These aren't the only
go-to-market strategies. But in fact,
they're a good place

to start thinking about,
what's yours going to be? Helpful?

Yes, no? OK, I just want
to say this again. The government
acquisition process

is not designed for us,
meaning Silicon Valley. It's not. It is incredibly complex,
inherently unfriendly,

trying to get better. But we need to
learn how they work, not that they will adopt
and adapt in our lifetime

to work the way we work. And so you just
need to understand what you're up against.

I just put up this list. If you're going to start
a business in the DoD,

the cost of entry is being
able to not only understand the buzzwords but actually
deeply understanding

what these processes are. There are lots of people who
could teach you this stuff. There are consultants. There are classes here
at Stanford, et cetera.

But this is the
minimum of trying to understand acquisition. Eric, am I missing
anything on the list?

Anything you would add? Oh, just a few hundred. A few hundred. Any core ones that
are just missing?

So there's a whole-- yes, there
are a couple hundred buzzwords. These are the ones that
popped into my head of like,

I didn't even know
what these meant. And these are kind of
fundamental to even have a conversation about
how the DoD buys and builds.

So the way you get educated,
talk to other startups. And taking this class
was a good place

to hear some of their voices. But if you're in a specific
niche or a specific area, I would reach out to those CEOs.

All of them have,
excuse the pun, war stories about trying
to sell that they'd be happy to share with you.

Talk to VCs who actually
have been in this space, are in this space, and have
a portfolio of companies.

Even if they won't
invest in you, they'd be happy to hear about
what you're thinking about. And in return, you
could ask them,

tell me the top three
mistakes that startups selling to the DoD make. Boy, I would not leave
the room until you

learn three new things. And then talk to consultants. There are plenty of people
who now are ex-military,

ex-acquisition who'd be
happy to take your money. And some of them are actually
useful in having you understand

how the system works. And we'll talk
about what a PEO is. A Program Executive
Officer will actually

manage some of these large
programs when they retire. They're looking for things
to do and happy to consult

or be advisors. There's something called
the Defense Acquisition University that trains
acquisition officers.

Their website is open. You could look at
some of their classes. At first glance, it
is unintelligible

and will blow your mind. These people need
to learn this stuff. But if you dig deep
enough, you could actually

get some good tutorials
on how the system works. And then of course, take
Hacking for Defense, MS&E 297.

It's taught this quarter. Our final presentations
are when, Joe? June--

4th. June 4th. You're all invited at-- HR McMaster is speaking. HR McMaster will be
speaking at 5:00 PM.

And it goes to about 8 o'clock
of the presentation, so the final. And we'll show you
some of the slides

that the students have done
to figure all this stuff out. Let me give you a taste
of what you're up against.

This is the simplified,
simplified view of the Department of
Defense acquisition paths.

In reality, just even thinking
about the number of contracts they have look more like this.

And this is just the
simplified, simplified version of the types of contracts. It is incredibly
